title: Arkansas Amendment Era (1874–Present)
preview: Since the adoption of the 1874 Constitution, Arkansas has operated under a framework intentionally designed to resist structural change. The Amendment Era is defined by a continuous struggle between: - popular efforts to modernize governance, and - elite efforts to contain, delay, dilute, or procedurally block reform.

title: Arkansas Constitution of 1861
preview: The Arkansas Constitution of 1861 was adopted in the immediate aftermath of Arkansas’ decision to secede from the United States and join the Confederate States of America.

title: Arkansas Constitution of 1868
preview: The Arkansas Constitution of 1868 was adopted during Congressional Reconstruction under direct federal oversight. Unlike prior constitutions, it was explicitly shaped by the aftermath of the Civil War, the abolition of slavery, and the federal mandate to reconstruct Southern governance on new terms.

title: Arkansas Political Eras \u2014 Foundational Periodization
preview: This document defines the primary political eras of Arkansas history as an organizing framework for research, data modeling, and narrative construction.

title: Arkansas Political History Project
preview: Documented the Arkansas Constitution of 1874. Analyzed it as a deliberate rollback of Reconstruction and a long-term power entrenchment mechanism. Connected constitutional design choices to modern governance dynamics.

preview: Before Arkansas became a state, it was governed as a U.S. territory. This period established many of the power dynamics that would later be embedded in the 1836 Constitution.

title: Power Frameworks
preview: This is not a glossary. This is not neutral. This is not “civics.”

title: Backlash as System
preview: Most people think backlash is emotional.

title: Elite Continuity Through Turnover
preview: Power does not depend on specific people.

preview: In mature power systems, repression is risky.

title: Geographic Dilution of Power
preview: Power does not only operate through laws and institutions.

preview: Power does not only reside in authority.

title: Legitimacy Laundering
preview: Power does not need to be just.

title: Procedural Supremacy
preview: Procedural supremacy occurs when power no longer argues *what* should happen.

preview: Power in Arkansas is often exercised by **those who control access**, not those who cast final votes.
